merged_dataset_groups.topic_summary: The BIOPEP dataset is used to categorize proteins as potential sources of bioactive fragments and to characterize food-derived peptides, focusing on sequence-activity relationships. It supports in silico digestion simulations to assess peptide stability under various enzymatic conditions, particularly hydrolysis percentages. Researchers also use it to identify and analyze antioxidant peptides, examining their sequence-activity relationships and structural motifs. This dataset enables detailed investigations into the functional properties of peptides, enhancing understanding of their biological activities.

The SOR database is used to compile antioxidative peptides from various protein sources, focusing on their sequence-activity relationships and structural motifs. Researchers employ this dataset to analyze and identify specific sequences and structures that correlate with antioxidative activities, aiding in the understanding of how peptide structure influences functionality. This compilation supports the development of new antioxidants by providing insights into effective molecular designs.

The BIOPEP Database is used to verify the novelty of identified antioxidant peptides and to identify bioactive peptides from bovine meat proteins. It focuses on the release of bioactive fragments by specific enzymes and their sequence-activity relationships through computational analysis. This enables researchers to ensure the uniqueness of their findings and to explore potential precursors of biologically active peptides.

merged_dataset_groups.topic_summary: The dataset of protein hydrolysate of croceine croaker scales is used to identify and characterize antioxidant peptides, specifically focusing on the sequence-activity relationships and structural motifs in marine organisms. This involves analyzing peptide sequences to understand their antioxidant properties and structural features, enabling researchers to explore the bioactive potential of marine-derived peptides.

The AAindex dataset is used to characterize tripeptides by providing amino acid indices, which aids in the analysis of peptide sequences and their potential antioxidant activities. This dataset enables researchers to systematically evaluate the physicochemical properties of amino acids, facilitating the identification of key features that correlate with antioxidant potential.

The GVPLT dataset is used to identify antioxidant peptides from bluefin leatherjacket heads, focusing on the sequence-activity relationships and structural motifs. Researchers employ this dataset to analyze the specific sequences and structures of peptides that exhibit antioxidant properties, enabling a deeper understanding of their functional mechanisms.

The UniProt dataset is used to select plant storage proteins for studying antioxidant peptides, focusing on their sequence-activity relationships and structural motifs. Researchers utilize the dataset to identify and analyze specific protein sequences, enabling a deeper understanding of how structural features influence antioxidant activity. This approach supports the development of novel antioxidant peptides with enhanced biological functions.

The NCBI database is used to provide amino acid sequences of sheep plasma proteins and antioxidant peptides, which serve as a foundation for analyzing the sequence-activity relationships of these peptides. This dataset enables researchers to correlate specific peptide sequences with their antioxidant activities, facilitating a deeper understanding of the structural determinants of antioxidant function.

The 'two tripeptide libraries' dataset is used to study the antioxidative activity of peptides, specifically focusing on the sequence-activity relationships and structural motifs within tripeptide sequences. This dataset enables researchers to identify key structural elements that influence antioxidative properties, facilitating a deeper understanding of peptide functionality.

The dataset of 108 structurally related tripeptides is used to study the antioxidative properties of tripeptides, particularly focusing on the activity of Pro-His-His in the linoleic acid peroxidation system. Combinatorial chemistry methods are employed to explore the sequence-activity relationships, enabling researchers to identify and understand the specific tripeptide structures that exhibit strong antioxidative effects.

The dataset of ninety-one synthetic antioxidant tripeptides is used to investigate the sequence-activity relationships of antioxidant peptides. Researchers focus on identifying structural motifs and their corresponding antioxidant properties, employing the dataset to analyze how specific peptide sequences influence antioxidant activity. This enables a deeper understanding of the molecular mechanisms underlying antioxidant functionality.
